text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cajun chicken ragout that's
right this mardi gras inspired recipe
may not be exactly like something you'd
see in orleans but it is inspired by
those flavors and style of cooking and
I've actually been to New Orleans twice
and one thing I learned down there is
they don't care who made it or what it's
called all they care about is whether
it's bone or not and this this is pretty
bone so anyway let me show you how to
make this this is one of my favorite
all-time comfort foods and it starts
with bacon always a good sign so we're
going to cut up five or six slices of
bacon we're going to throw it in a cold
pan on medium heat and we're going to
cook it stirring occasionally until it's
basically crisp we want to render out
all that bacon fat because that's what
we're going to use the saute vegetables
when the bacon is crisp and looks like
that we're going to turn the heat off
and remove that to a bowl with a slotted
spoon all right we're going to reserve
that we're going to use that later of
course and we're pretty much going to
leave all that bacon grease in the pan
you should have at least a couple
tablespoons alright so once we've done
that we can put the heat back on medium
and we're going to go ahead and add our
celery and onions to the pan with a big
pinch of salt we're going to cook that
stirring for about five minutes until
the onions start to turn translucent and
then we're going to add our diced bell
peppers and a little bit of garlic and
we're going to cook that for about five
minutes on medium heat and by the way
peppers celery and onions are referred
to down in New Orleans as the Holy
Trinity that's right the Father the Son
and the Holy Ghost the peppers of the
father they're the most vengeful are the
celery is the Sun a little bit bitter
probably that whole time for our sins
thing and the onions of course of the
Holy Ghost because they're white like a
ghost and yes that was a little
sacrilegious okay at that point our
vegetable mixture should be getting nice
and soft and sweet and succulent and it
should look something like that and we
obviously already have the bacon fat in
here but I'm going to add about another
tablespoon of fat with just some
vegetable oil to make sure we have
enough to make the roux Andrew of course
flour cooked in some kind of fat so
we're going to drizzle that in and then
we're going to sprinkle over our flour
just regular white all-purpose flour
we're going to take our spoon again
we're going to stay right on medium heat
we're going to stir that in and we're
going to cook that for about five
minutes now unlike a traditional rule
which is just flour and fat in the pan
we also have these very moist vegetables
so this will be a little gummy err a
little wetter a little more difficult to
work with but don't worry just leave
your
down medium I just keep scraping with
your wooden spoon
keeping it move in all right so while
that Roux is cooking let's go ahead and
add some spices in we're gonna dump in
some freshly ground black pepper some
paprika oops I spilled some don't be a
stubborn cook I didn't want that much so
I took a little out don't just stir it
in because you spilled it you can always
add more later you can't take it out
we're going to add some cayenne pepper
of course and a nice big pinch of dry
oregano
all right stir that into your Roux which
by now is pretty much cooked and you'll
notice towards the end it should start
sticking and kind of toasting against
the bottom of your pan which is no
problem because the next step is
deglazing so we're going to take some
chicken stock we're going to dump in
about a half a cup give it a stir our
broth or stock or whatever we're using
is cold you know the old saying ha true
cold stock no lumps are we going to
splash some more in give it a stir and
once I have about half of it in and I
can see there's no major lump age
happening just go ahead and dump the
rest in give it a stir and then we can
raise our heat up to medium-high because
we want this to come up to a nice simmer
and I'm going to simmer that for about
five or ten minutes I want to cook out
the last of the raw taste of the flour
and I also want to reduce it to thicken
it up a bit okay so you can see that
they're bubbling nicely we're also going
to give it a little shot of
Worcestershire sauce pretty much
mandatory for things like this and that
is looking pretty good so after about 10
minutes of simmering I was very happy
with the thickness of mine so I turned
it down to low and the last step we're
going to add some sausage and chicken
now I'm using some sliced and Dewey
sausage which is a very traditional
Cajun sausage we're also going to add in
our cooked bacon from earlier by the way
protip if you want to save a little bit
to garnish the top with later that's not
a bad idea so I saved a little bit and
then last but not least some cooked
chicken and this is perfect for when you
have leftover roast chicken you could
just poach a couple breasts and shred
them that's actually what I did for this
one and let me tell you you expose a
couple nice breasts to a gravy like this
you will be getting some offers for
beans
trust me and of course if you want to
use raw chicken you certainly could just
cut it up in small pieces stir it in
you'll just have to keep it on the heat
till the chickens cooked obviously and
once our chicken and sausage is heated
through we're going to throw in a
handful of green onions give that a stir
of course you're going to check for
final seasoning it might need some salt
might need a little more spice up to you
but that's pretty much it alright and
once you've made those final adjustments
go ahead and spoon this up over
something I suggest perfectly made white
rice but this would be equally delicious
over grits over pasta over potatoes
alright pretty much anything or just eat
it playing with a nice salad just like
they would never do in New Orleans ok
we're gonna garnish with a few bacon
bits
a few more green onions and that like I
said the beginning is tray bone am I
saying that right
what I'm trying to say is it's really
really good chicken and gravy over rice
is of course a classic and then when you
include the bacon and the spicy sausage
and the Holy Trinity of vegetables
giving it that aromatic base it's just a
really great dish and as you saw easy to
make and doesn't really take that long
so I really hope you give this a try
head over to food wishes comm for all
the agreed amount and more info as usual
and as always enjoy
